awd_titl_txt: Syndication of the Film Secrets of the Surface: The Mathematical Vision of Maryam Mirzakhani
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award supports the preparation of a documentary film about mathematician Maryam Mirzakhani for national broadcast on public television via American Public Television syndication (APT) in November 2021 or March 2022. This documentary, "Secrets of the Surface: The Mathematical Vision of Maryam Mirzakhani", directed by George Csicsery, had its world premiere at the Joint Mathematics Meeting in Denver, Colorado in January 2020. The 60-minute film has had wide distribution in DVD and streaming, and numerous public screenings at universities and film festivals since the premiere. The film has proven highly effective at conveying mathematical ideas to the general public through the human story of Mirzakhani, a leading mathematician who became the first woman to win the Fields Medal (2014). The film chronicles her education in Iran through graduate school at Harvard, and her numerous mathematical breakthroughs, before her untimely death in 2017. Mirzakhani’s story, as told in the film, has proven inspirational to girls studying STEM subjects and to women choosing mathematics as a career. Her example as an Iranian woman who reached the top of her field demonstrates the possibility of overcoming gender and cultural barriers. The film also shows how formidable cultural differences, in this case between Iran and the United States, can be overcome through the pursuit of knowledge and pure science.

Modification of the film for public television broadcast involves editing, adding required modules, closed captioning, and other technical work, as well as promotional efforts aimed at individual station programmers in the public television system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal was to prepare the 2020 documentary film by George Csicsery, Secrets of the Surface: The Mathematical Vision of Maryam Mirzakhani for public television broadcast by way of syndication through American Public Television (APT) and to promote the broadcasts to increase viewership. The completed film and a 30-second trailer were delivered to APT, which launched it for broadcast in late February 2022. A station relations representative promoted the film to individual programmers at the stations in the public broadcasting system.


Secrets of the Surface presents a unique opportunity to learn about the extraordinary mathematical contributions of Maryam Mirzakhani, a remarkable mathematician whose life serves to inspire young women, historically underrepresented in the mathematical sciences, and whose work suggests links between mathematics and Iranian art.


Beyond an examination of pure mathematical principles, the film demystifies the process of creating mathematics, thus contributing to the public’s understanding of how research advances. Key to this process is the role played by the Iranian educational system, rarely depicted and prominently featured in this film. As such, the film offers US audiences a unique cross-cultural perspective. The result is a startling realization of Mirzakhani’s profound contributions--often described as beautiful by her colleagues--to Teichmuller theory, hyperbolic geometry, ergodic theory, and symplectic geometry. Mirzakhani’s profound contributions to the field come to life through explanations by leading mathematicians such as Alex Eskin, her collaborator and winner of the Breakthrough Prize (2020), and illustrated animated sequences. 


The film’s insightful analysis of Mirzakhani’s contributions to mathematics and its portrayal of Mirzakhani’s life and mathematical work is an inspiration to young women to pursue careers in math, Secrets of the Surface is unlike anything else available.


In her report to the producer of 3/31/22, Kristin Fellows, the station relations rep, cited the following statistics from the broadcasts to date: “Our premiere month was March for Women’s History Month, and that worked well as a strategy. Secrets of the Surface has an exceptional run with 764 airdates on 375 PBS stations & channels in 152 markets across 46 states covering 90% of the US."
